description: Borrowed from Middle French canal, from Old French canal, from Latin canālis (“channel; canal”), from canālis (“canal”), from canna (“reed, cane”), from Ancient Greek κάννα (kánna, “reed”), from Akkadian 𒄀 (qanû, “reed”), from Sumerian 𒄀𒈾 (gi.na). Doublet of channel.

entries.meaning: An artificial waterway or artificially improved river used for travel, shipping, or irrigation.
(anatomy) A tubular channel within the body.
(astronomy) One of the faint, hazy markings resembling straight lines on early telescopic images of the surface of Mars; see Martian canals

verbs.description: canal (third-person singular simple present canals, present participle canaling or canalling, simple past and past participle canaled or canalled)

entries.meaning: To dig an artificial waterway in or to (a place), especially for drainage
To travel along a canal by boat
